inscribed: According to Florent Heintz (2000, p. 166) the curse inscribed in Greek, “aimed at a greengrocer named Babylas, a typically Antiochene name made popular by a bishop and saint of the mid third century. [It] gives the demon in charge of carrying out the spell precise genealogical and topographical information concerning his target: the three different aliases the shopkeeper’s mother assumed, as well as the city block and even the precise location on a colonnaded street of his vegetable stall.  The demon is repeatedly asked to “bind” Babylas, to “lay him low” to “stink him like lead,” to destroy his animals and his house in general.”
